articles.title: Adolescence
articles.context: Puberty occurs through a long process and begins with a surge in hormone production, which in turn causes a number of physical changes. It is the stage of life characterized by the appearance and development of secondary sex characteristics (for example, a deeper voice and larger adam's apple in boys, and development of breasts and more curved and prominent hips in girls) and a strong shift in hormonal balance towards an adult state. This is triggered by the pituitary gland, which secretes a surge of hormonal agents into the blood stream, initiating a chain reaction to occur. The male and female gonads are subsequently activated, which puts them into a state of rapid growth and development; the triggered gonads now commence the mass production of the necessary chemicals. The testes primarily release testosterone, and the ovaries predominantly dispense estrogen. The production of these hormones increases gradually until sexual maturation is met. Some boys may develop gynecomastia due to an imbalance of sex hormones, tissue responsiveness or obesity.

6. Testosterone is primarily produced by the testes in boys, while estrogen is primarily produced by the ovaries in girls.
7. Testosterone and estrogen production increase gradually until sexual maturation is reached.
8. Gynecomastia, an imbalance of sex hormones, tissue responsiveness, or obesity, can cause some boys to develop breast-like growths during puberty.

articles.title: Child labour
articles.context: Throughout the second half of the 19th century, child labour began to decline in industrialised societies due to regulation and economic factors. The regulation of child labour began from the earliest days of the Industrial revolution. The first act to regulate child labour in Britain was passed in 1803. As early as 1802 and 1819 Factory Acts were passed to regulate the working hours of workhouse children in factories and cotton mills to 12 hours per day. These acts were largely ineffective and after radical agitation, by for example the "Short Time Committees" in 1831, a Royal Commission recommended in 1833 that children aged 11–18 should work a maximum of 12 hours per day, children aged 9–11 a maximum of eight hours, and children under the age of nine were no longer permitted to work. This act however only applied to the textile industry, and further agitation led to another act in 1847 limiting both adults and children to 10-hour working days. Lord Shaftesbury was an outspoken advocate of regulating child labour.

articles.title: Botany
articles.context: Nonvascular land plants are embryophytes that lack the vascular tissues xylem and phloem. They include mosses, liverworts and hornworts. Pteridophytic vascular plants with true xylem and phloem that reproduced by spores germinating into free-living gametophytes evolved during the Silurian period and diversified into several lineages during the late Silurian and early Devonian. Representatives of the lycopods have survived to the present day. By the end of the Devonian period, several groups, including the lycopods, sphenophylls and progymnosperms, had independently evolved "megaspory" – their spores were of two distinct sizes, larger megaspores and smaller microspores. Their reduced gametophytes developed from megaspores retained within the spore-producing organs (megasporangia) of the sporophyte, a condition known as endospory. Seeds consist of an endosporic megasporangium surrounded by one or two sheathing layers (integuments). The young sporophyte develops within the seed, which on germination splits to release it. The earliest known seed plants date from the latest Devonian Famennian stage. Following the evolution of the seed habit, seed plants diversified, giving rise to a number of now-extinct groups, including seed ferns, as well as the modern gymnosperms and angiosperms. Gymnosperms produce "naked seeds" not fully enclosed in an ovary; modern representatives include conifers, cycads, Ginkgo, and Gnetales. Angiosperms produce seeds enclosed in a structure such as a carpel or an ovary. Ongoing research on the molecular phylogenetics of living plants appears to show that the angiosperms are a sister clade to the gymnosperms.

Given the implications you have derived from the passage, what can be inferred about the evolution and classification of plants?

From the implications I derived from the passage, several inferences can be made about the evolution and classification of plants. The development of the seed habit and the subsequent diversification of plants were important evolutionary events that gave rise to new groups of plants. The evolution of vascular land plants and the megaspory phenomenon were key adaptations that contributed to the successful colonization of land by plants. The differentiation between gymnosperms and angiosperms reflects the diverse reproductive strategies employed by different groups of plants. The classification of plants as nonvascular, vascular with different types of reproduction, and seed plants is based on their evolutionary history and their distinct features. These classifications help biologists to understand the relationships between different groups of plants and their ecological roles in their respective environments.

Considering the evolution and classification of plants, how might the adaptability of gymnosperms and angiosperms to different environmental conditions influence their distribution and abundance in diverse ecosystems?

Gymnosperms and angiosperms, despite their similarities, have adapted to diverse environments and can be found in most ecosystems across the world. These adaptations have influenced their distribution and abundance in different environments.

Angiosperms, also known as flowering plants, have a higher diversity and can be found in more varied habitats. They have adapted to a wide range of environmental conditions, including tropical rainforests, deserts, and arctic tundras. Some angiosperms have adapted to living in challenging conditions such as high altitudes or dry deserts. Their flowers have evolved to attract specific pollinators, which helps increase their chances of successful reproduction in these environments. Additionally, many angiosperms have evolved adaptations such as deep taproots or drought-resistant leaves, allowing them to survive in extreme environments.

Gymnosperms, on the other hand, have adapted to a range of environments but are often more specialized in their habitat preferences. Conifers, for example, are well-suited to cold, harsh environments like alpine regions and boreal forests. Gymnosperms' needle-like leaves and waxy cuticles help them retain water and resist harsh conditions. Their ability to grow in cold, nutrient-poor soils also makes them well-suited to environments where other plants struggle to survive. 

Despite their differences, both gymnosperms and angiosperms have successfully diversified and adapted to various environments, allowing them to be found in most ecosystems worldwide. The adaptability of these groups of plants has likely played a significant role in their distribution and abundance in diverse ecosystems.

Based on the adaptations of gymnosperms and angiosperms, how might climate change and increasing anthropogenic disturbance impact the distribution and abundance of these plant groups in different ecosystems?

Climate change and increasing anthropogenic disturbance are likely to significantly impact the distribution and abundance of both gymnosperms and angiosperms in different ecosystems.

For angiosperms, which are often more sensitive to environmental changes, climate change could reduce their range and abundance. Changes in temperature and rainfall patterns could negatively impact their ability to reproduce, grow, and survive in certain environments. For example, warmer temperatures and changing rainfall patterns could cause some angiosperm species to shift their ranges towards cooler areas, potentially leaving others vulnerable to extinction. Furthermore, climate change could also lead to the loss of critical habitats, making it challenging for many species to survive and reproduce.

Gymnosperms, which tend to be more resilient to environmental changes, may face increased competition from angiosperms due to the latter's greater adaptability and capacity for rapid reproduction. Climate change could also reduce their range and abundance by altering their preferred habitats and making it difficult for them to compete with other plant species in the same environment. For instance, coniferous forests, which are home to many gymnosperm species, could experience significant die-offs due to changing weather patterns or increased forest disturbances, leading to a decline in their abundance and range.

Anthropogenic disturbance, such as deforestation and urbanization, could also have significant impacts on both gymnosperms and angiosperms. These disturbances can directly impact the plants by reducing their habitat and causing declines in their populations. They can also indirectly affect them by altering the composition of their ecosystems. For example, deforestation could lead to soil erosion, reduced water quality, and changes in microclimate, which could negatively affect both types of plants. Additionally, increased greenhouse gas emissions could exacerbate the impacts of anthropogenic disturbances, further reducing the abundance and range of both gymnosperms and angiosperms.

Following the evolution of the seed habit, seed plants diversified, giving rise to a number of now-extinct groups, including seed ferns, as well as the modern gymnosperms and angiosperms. Gymnosperms produce "naked seeds" not fully enclosed in an ovary; modern representatives include conifers, cycads, Ginkgo, and Gnetales. Angiosperms produce seeds enclosed in a structure such as a carpel or an ovary. Ongoing research on the molecular phylogenetics of living plants appears to show that the angiosperms are a sister clade to the gymnosperms.

articles.title: Hellenistic period
articles.context: In 215 BC Philip, with his eye on Illyria, formed an alliance with Rome's enemy Hannibal of Carthage, which led to Roman alliances with the Achaean League, Rhodes and Pergamum. The First Macedonian War broke out in 212 BC, and ended inconclusively in 205 BC. Philip continued to wage war against Pergamon and Rhodes for control of the Aegean (204-200 BCE) and ignored Roman demands for non-intervention in Greece by invading Attica. In 198 BC, during the Second Macedonian War Philip was decisively defeated at Cynoscephalae by the Roman proconsul Titus Quinctius Flamininus and Macedon lost all its territories in Greece proper. Greece was now thoroughly brought into the Roman sphere of influence, though it retained nominal autonomy. The end of Antigonid Macedon came when Philip V's son, Perseus, was defeated and captured by the Romans in the Third Macedonian War (171–168 BCE).

The mention of the First Macedonian War and subsequent conflicts shows the need for resolution through military engagements or diplomacy to maintain peace and stability in the region.

7. **Strategic Importance of Territory**: Areas like Illyria, Greece, and the Aegean were strategically crucial for influence in the region. Control over these territories was sought by various powers, indicating their importance in trade routes, resources, and cultural exchange.

8. **Effect of Military Defeats on Leadership**: The capture of Perseus by the Romans underscores the vulnerability of leaders and the consequences of failure in warfare. It can lead to changes in leadership structures and shifts in political power.

10. **Long-Term Economic and Social Consequences**: The wars and changes in leadership had long-term impacts on the social fabric and economic conditions of the affected areas, affecting everything from trade to employment opportunities.

articles.title: Super Nintendo Entertainment System
articles.context: Internally, a regional lockout chip (CIC) within the console and in each cartridge prevents PAL region games from being played on Japanese or North American consoles and vice versa. The Japanese and North American machines have the same region chip. This can be overcome through the use of adapters, typically by inserting the imported cartridge in one slot and a cartridge with the correct region chip in a second slot. Alternatively, disconnecting one pin of the console's lockout chip will prevent it from locking the console; hardware in later games can detect this situation, so it later became common to install a switch to reconnect the lockout chip as needed.

articles.title: Saint Helena
articles.context: Englishman Sir Francis Drake probably located the island on the final leg of his circumnavigation of the world (1577–1580). Further visits by other English explorers followed, and, once Saint Helena’s location was more widely known, English ships of war began to lie in wait in the area to attack Portuguese India carracks on their way home. In developing their Far East trade, the Dutch also began to frequent the island. The Portuguese and Spanish soon gave up regularly calling at the island, partly because they used ports along the West African coast, but also because of attacks on their shipping, the desecration of their chapel and religious icons, destruction of their livestock and destruction of plantations by Dutch and English sailors.

articles.title: Czech language
articles.context: The similarities between Czech and Slovak led to the languages being considered a single language by a group of 19th-century scholars who called themselves "Czechoslavs" (Čechoslováci), believing that the peoples were connected in a way which excluded German Bohemians and (to a lesser extent) Hungarians and other Slavs. During the First Czechoslovak Republic (1918–1938), although "Czechoslovak" was designated as the republic's official language both Czech and Slovak written standards were used. Standard written Slovak was partially modeled on literary Czech, and Czech was preferred for some official functions in the Slovak half of the republic. Czech influence on Slovak was protested by Slovak scholars, and when Slovakia broke off from Czechoslovakia in 1938 as the Slovak State (which then aligned with Nazi Germany in World War II) literary Slovak was deliberately distanced from Czech. When the Axis powers lost the war and Czechoslovakia reformed, Slovak developed somewhat on its own (with Czech influence); during the Prague Spring of 1968, Slovak gained independence from (and equality with) Czech. Since then, "Czechoslovak" refers to improvised pidgins of the languages which have arisen from the decrease in mutual intelligibility.

Passage:
Czech language
The similarities between Czech and Slovak led to the languages being considered a single language by a group of 19th-century scholars who called themselves "Czechoslavs" (Čechoslováci), believing that the peoples were connected in a way which excluded German Bohemians and (to a lesser extent) Hungarians and other Slavs. During the First Czechoslovak Republic (1918–1938), although "Czechoslovak" was designated as the republic's official language both Czech and Slovak written standards were used. Standard written Slovak was partially modeled on literary Czech, and Czech was preferred for some official functions in the Slovak half of the republic. Czech influence on Slovak was protested by Slovak scholars, and when Slovakia broke off from Czechoslovakia in 1938 as the Slovak State (which then aligned with Nazi Germany in World War II) literary Slovak was deliberately distanced from Czech. When the Axis powers lost the war and Czechoslovakia reformed, Slovak developed somewhat on its own (with Czech influence); during the Prague Spring of 1968, Slovak gained independence from (and equality with) Czech. Since then, "Czechoslovak" refers to improvised pidgins of the languages which have arisen from the decrease in mutual intelligibility.

articles.title: Franco-Prussian War
articles.context: With the defeat of Marshal Bazaine's Army of the Rhine at Gravelotte, the French were forced to retire to Metz, where they were besieged by over 150,000 Prussian troops of the First and Second Armies. Napoleon III and MacMahon formed the new French Army of Châlons, to march on to Metz to rescue Bazaine. Napoleon III personally led the army with Marshal MacMahon in attendance. The Army of Châlons marched northeast towards the Belgian border to avoid the Prussians before striking south to link up with Bazaine. The Prussians, under the command of Field Marshal Count Helmuth von Moltke, took advantage of this maneuver to catch the French in a pincer grip. He left the Prussian First and Second Armies besieging Metz, except three corps detached to form the Army of the Meuse under the Crown Prince of Saxony. With this army and the Prussian Third Army, Moltke marched northward and caught up with the French at Beaumont on 30 August. After a sharp fight in which they lost 5,000 men and 40 cannons, the French withdrew toward Sedan. Having reformed in the town, the Army of Châlons was immediately isolated by the converging Prussian armies. Napoleon III ordered the army to break out of the encirclement immediately. With MacMahon wounded on the previous day, General Auguste Ducrot took command of the French troops in the field.

Franco-Prussian War
With the defeat of Marshal Bazaine's Army of the Rhine at Gravelotte, the French were forced to retire to Metz, where they were besieged by over 150,000 Prussian troops of the First and Second Armies. The Army of Châlons marched northeast towards the Belgian border to avoid the Prussians before striking south to link up with Bazaine. The Prussians, under the command of Field Marshal Count Helmuth von Moltke, took advantage of this maneuver to catch the French in a pincer grip. He left the Prussian First and Second Armies besieging Metz, except three corps detached to form the Army of the Meuse under the Crown Prince of Saxony. With this army and the Prussian Third Army, Moltke marched northward and caught up with the French at Beaumont on 30 August. After a sharp fight in which they lost 5,000 men and 40 cannons, the French withdrew toward Sedan. Having reformed in the town, the Army of Châlons was immediately isolated by the converging Prussian armies. Napoleon III ordered the army to break out of the encirclement immediately. With MacMahon wounded on the previous day, General Auguste Ducrot took command of the French troops in the field.

articles.title: Capacitor
articles.context: In electric power distribution, capacitors are used for power factor correction. Such capacitors often come as three capacitors connected as a three phase load. Usually, the values of these capacitors are given not in farads but rather as a reactive power in volt-amperes reactive (var). The purpose is to counteract inductive loading from devices like electric motors and transmission lines to make the load appear to be mostly resistive. Individual motor or lamp loads may have capacitors for power factor correction, or larger sets of capacitors (usually with automatic switching devices) may be installed at a load center within a building or in a large utility substation.

7. Capacitors play a significant role in improving the efficiency of electric power distribution systems.

articles.title: Copyright infringement
articles.context: United States v. LaMacchia 871 F.Supp. 535 (1994) was a case decided by the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts which ruled that, under the copyright and cybercrime laws effective at the time, committing copyright infringement for non-commercial motives could not be prosecuted under criminal copyright law. The ruling gave rise to what became known as the "LaMacchia Loophole," wherein criminal charges of fraud or copyright infringement would be dismissed under current legal standards, so long as there was no profit motive involved.

completions.text:
1. The ruling in United States v. LaMacchia 871 F.Supp. 535 suggests that, without a profit motive, criminal charges for copyright infringement or fraud may not be viable under current legal standards.
2. The case established a precedent for the "LaMacchia Loophole," a concept that allows defendants to avoid criminal prosecution for non-commercial copyright infringement due to the absence of a profit motive.
3. The lack of a profit motive in copyright infringement cases may result in lighter penalties or no penalties being imposed on the defendant.
4. This loophole may create a sense of security for individuals who engage in non-commercial copyright infringement activities, as they are less likely to face criminal charges.
5. The ruling may encourage the continuation of non-commercial copyright infringement without any fear of criminal repercussions.
6. The case highlights the complexity of copyright law and its ability to vary depending on the circumstances of each individual case.

3. The legal standards at the time of the ruling were insufficient to address all forms of copyright infringement, particularly those committed without a profit motive.
4. The decision in this case emphasizes the importance of updating copyright and cybercrime laws to ensure they cover all potential forms of infringement and adequately protect creators' intellectual property.
5. The LaMacchia Loophole highlights the need for legal and regulatory clarity on the scope of criminal copyright infringement, particularly in relation to non-commercial or non-profit activities.
6. This case underscores the fact that copyright law should not be based solely on profit motive; it should also consider the broader implications of infringement on the creative and intellectual property industries.
7. The ruling in this case suggests that defendants may exploit legal loopholes to avoid criminal prosecution for copyright infringement, further demonstrating the need for continuous updates and improvements to copyright and cybercrime laws.

4. The LaMacchia case highlights the importance of addressing the legal consequences of non-commercial copyright infringement.
5. The LaMacchia case underscores the need for lawmakers to consider the potential impact of legal loopholes on the enforcement of copyright law.

articles.title: Indigenous peoples of the Americas
articles.context: About 5% of the Nicaraguan population are indigenous. The largest indigenous group in Nicaragua is the Miskito people. Their territory extended from Cape Camarón, Honduras, to Rio Grande, Nicaragua along the Mosquito Coast. There is a native Miskito language, but large groups speak Miskito Coast Creole, Spanish, Rama and other languages. The Creole English came about through frequent contact with the British who colonized the area. Many are Christians. Traditional Miskito society was highly structured with a defined political structure. There was a king, but he did not have total power. Instead, the power was split between himself, a governor, a general, and by the 1750s, an admiral. Historical information on kings is often obscured by the fact that many of the kings were semi-mythical. Another major group is the Mayangna (or Sumu) people, counting some 10,000 people.

4. The introduction of English-speaking Creole through frequent contact with the British who colonized the area has led to the prevalence of Creole English among some Miskito communities.
5. The religious beliefs and practices of the Miskito people include Christianity, highlighting the influence of external religious influences on their beliefs.
6. Miskito society had a complex political structure with roles for a king, governor, general, and admiral, indicating a well-established social and organizational hierarchy.
7. Historical information on Miskito kings is often marred by the inclusion of semi-mythical elements, suggesting that there may have been a blending of fact and folklore in their oral traditions.
8. The Mayangna (or Sumu) people represent another major indigenous group in Nicaragua, with a population of around 10,000 individuals.

articles.title: Czech language
articles.context: Czech typographical features not associated with phonetics generally resemble those of most Latin European languages, including English. Proper nouns, honorifics, and the first letters of quotations are capitalized, and punctuation is typical of other Latin European languages. Writing of ordinal numerals is similar to most European languages. The Czech language uses a decimal comma instead of a decimal point. When writing a long number, spaces between every three numbers (e.g. between hundreds and thousands) may be used for better orientation in handwritten texts, but not in decimal places, like in English. The number 1,234,567.8910 may be written as 1234567,8910 or 1 234 567,8910. Ordinal numbers (1st) use a point as in German (1.). In proper noun phrases (except personal names), only the first word is capitalized (Pražský hrad, Prague Castle).

Von Neumann oversaw computations related to the expected size of the bomb blasts, estimated death tolls, and the distance above the ground at which the bombs should be detonated for optimum shock wave propagation and thus maximum effect. The cultural capital Kyoto, which had been spared the bombing inflicted upon militarily significant cities, was von Neumann's first choice, a selection seconded by Manhattan Project leader General Leslie Groves. However, this target was dismissed by Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson.

articles.context: Min Nan texts, all Hokkien, can be dated back to the 16th century. It is known as Pumindian.

Here's a discussion on the implications derived from the passage about Hokkien:

1. **Long Historical Presence**: The fact that Min Nan texts date back to the 16th century (with examples like the Doctrina Christiana en letra y lengua china and the Romance of the Lychee Mirror) suggests that Hokkien has a long and established history. This implies that Hokkien has been in existence and has been used as a language for communication and literature for over four centuries.

This implies that Hokkien dialects may have significant linguistic variations.

3. **Role in Education and Cross-Cultural Communication**: The existence of a language teaching book for foreigners and Chinese non-speakers indicates a significant interest in spreading awareness and use of Hokkien internationally. This implies that Hokkien is not only important within its native regions but also has a potential role in promoting cultural exchange and understanding globally.

This suggests a level of political and economic support for Hokkien, potentially indicating its importance in certain political or economic contexts.

5. **Social Significance**: The fact that this language has been used as a tool for international communication, specifically the Doctrina Christiana en letra y lengua china, speaks to the social significance of Hokkien in historical contexts. This implies that Hokkien has played a role in connecting people from different cultures and faiths.

6. **Preservation Efforts**: The development of resources for teaching Hokkien to foreigners and non-speakers suggests efforts to preserve and promote the language. This could imply concern about the potential decline or disappearance of Hokkien, leading to efforts to ensure it remains accessible to new generations and non-native speakers.

7. **Language Diversity in China**: The presence of Hokkien indicates the language diversity within China, which might influence the study of regional languages and dialects within the country and beyond.

8. **Scholarly and Linguistic Interest**: The creation of an alphabet, dictionary, and language teaching book by Xiamen University implies scholarly and linguistic interest in Hokkien. This might contribute to academic research and understanding of the language’s structure, history, and development.

9. **Potential for Identity and Cultural Revival**: The increased focus on teaching Hokkien to non-speakers and foreigners could be seen as a step towards cultural revival or strengthening Hokkien identity, especially in areas where it is less commonly spoken or understood.

10. **Integration into Global Language Landscape**: The existence of a resource like the language teaching book also suggests that Hokkien is part of a global conversation about languages and their role in education and cross-cultural understanding. This indicates that Hokkien could play a role in shaping the future of global multilingualism.

What are the historical and geographical origins of Hokkien, and how has its usage evolved over time?
Hokkien (also known as Min Nan or Southern Min) is a group of Min Chinese dialects, primarily spoken in southern Fujian Province, Taiwan, and by overseas Chinese communities in Southeast Asia, particularly in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore. Here are some key points regarding its historical and geographical origins and evolution:

### Historical and Geographical Origins:
1. **Geographical Origin**: Hokkien originated in the southern regions of China, particularly in the coastal areas of Fujian Province. The name "Hokkien" itself comes from the Hokkien pronunciation of "Xiamen," the capital of Fujian Province, which was known as "Xiamen" in Mandarin Chinese.

2. **Ethnic Origins**: The people who speak Hokkien are largely descendants of the Han Chinese who migrated to Fujian from northern and central China during historical periods such as the Song Dynasty (960-1279). These migrants brought with them their dialects, which eventually evolved into what is now known as Hokkien.

3. **Spread to Other Regions**: Over time, Hokkien speakers began to migrate to other regions both within China (e.g., Guangdong) and overseas due to various reasons such as trade, diaspora, and forced migrations. This spread has led to variations in the dialect within the broader Hokkien linguistic family.

### Evolution Over Time:
1. **Development within Fujian**: Initially, Hokkien developed and thrived in Fujian Province. Its use grew with the increasing urbanization and commercial activities in the coastal cities, leading to the creation of a written form (like the Doctrina Christiana) that allowed for better communication across different domains and regions.

2. **Adaptation for International Use**: As Hokkien speakers moved overseas, especially to Southeast Asian countries, the language adapted to local contexts. For example, in Malaysia and Singapore, Hokkien became heavily influenced by Malay and English, leading to the development of unique slang and vocabulary. Similarly, in Indonesia, Hokkien borrowed words and grammar structures from Indonesian.

3. **Standardization and Education**: The 20th century saw efforts towards standardizing Hokkien through the creation of dictionaries and educational materials, such as the Pumindian alphabet and language teaching books. These efforts helped maintain and propagate the language, particularly among younger generations and in educational contexts.

4. **Government Policies and Cultural Revival**: In Malaysia and Singapore, the government implemented policies to promote the use of Mandarin Chinese as a national language while still recognizing and accommodating Hokkien and other Chinese dialects through initiatives like the Form 17 teaching program in Malaysia and the Speak Mandarin movement in Singapore. This reflects a balance between national unity and cultural diversity.

5. **Global Presence**: Today, Hokkien continues to be spoken by millions of people around the world, not just in its traditional homeland but also in various diaspora communities. This global presence underscores the language's resilience and adaptability over centuries.

In summary, Hokkien has deep roots in Fujian Province and has evolved through migration, adaptation to local environments, and efforts towards standardization and education. Its usage continues to shape and be shaped by the socio-political landscape of its speaking communities.

articles.title: Age of Enlightenment
articles.context: The Enlightenment has been frequently linked to the French Revolution of 1789. One view of the political changes that occurred during the Enlightenment is that the "consent of the governed" philosophy as delineated by Locke in Two Treatises of Government (1689) represented a paradigm shift from the old governance paradigm under feudalism known as the "divine right of kings". In this view, the revolutions of the late 1700s and early 1800s were caused by the fact that this governance paradigm shift often could not be resolved peacefully, and therefore violent revolution was the result. Clearly a governance philosophy where the king was never wrong was in direct conflict with one whereby citizens by natural law had to consent to the acts and rulings of their government.

articles.title: The Times
articles.context: Historically, the paper was not overtly pro-Tory or Whig, but has been a long time bastion of the English Establishment and empire. The Times adopted a stance described as "peculiarly detached" at the 1945 general election; although it was increasingly critical of the Conservative Party's campaign, it did not advocate a vote for any one party. However, the newspaper reverted to the Tories for the next election five years later. It supported the Conservatives for the subsequent three elections, followed by support for both the Conservatives and the Liberal Party for the next five elections, expressly supporting a Con-Lib coalition in 1974. The paper then backed the Conservatives solidly until 1997, when it declined to make any party endorsement but supported individual (primarily Eurosceptic) candidates.

articles.title: British Empire
articles.context: Britain retains sovereignty over 14 territories outside the British Isles, which were renamed the British Overseas Territories in 2002. Some are uninhabited except for transient military or scientific personnel; the remainder are self-governing to varying degrees and are reliant on the UK for foreign relations and defence. The British government has stated its willingness to assist any Overseas Territory that wishes to proceed to independence, where that is an option. British sovereignty of several of the overseas territories is disputed by their geographical neighbours: Gibraltar is claimed by Spain, the Falkland Islands and South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands are claimed by Argentina, and the British Indian Ocean Territory is claimed by Mauritius and Seychelles. The British Antarctic Territory is subject to overlapping claims by Argentina and Chile, while many countries do not recognise any territorial claims in Antarctica.

articles.title: Tuvalu
articles.context: From 1996 to 2002, Tuvalu was one of the best-performing Pacific Island economies and achieved an average real gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate of 5.6% per annum. Since 2002 economic growth has slowed, with GDP growth of 1.5% in 2008. Tuvalu was exposed to rapid rises in world prices of fuel and food in 2008, with the level of inflation peaking at 13.4%. The International Monetary Fund 2010 Report on Tuvalu estimates that Tuvalu experienced zero growth in its 2010 GDP, after the economy contracted by about 2% in 2009. On 5 August 2012, the Executive Board of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) concluded the Article IV consultation with Tuvalu, and assessed the economy of Tuvalu: "A slow recovery is underway in Tuvalu, but there are important risks. GDP grew in 2011 for the first time since the global financial crisis, led by the private retail sector and education spending. We expect growth to rise slowly". The IMF 2014 Country Report noted that real GDP growth in Tuvalu had been volatile averaging only 1 percent in the past decade. The 2014 Country Report describes economic growth prospects as generally positive as the result of large revenues from fishing licenses, together with substantial foreign aid.

articles.title: Hellenistic period
articles.context: After the Seleucid defeat at the Battle of Magnesia in 190 BC, the kings of Sophene and Greater Armenia revolted and declared their independence, with Artaxias becoming the first king of the Artaxiad dynasty of Armenia in 188. During the reign of the Artaxiads, Armenia went through a period of hellenization. Numismatic evidence shows Greek artistic styles and the use of the Greek language. Some coins describe the Armenian kings as "Philhellenes". During the reign of Tigranes the Great (95–55 BC), the kingdom of Armenia reached its greatest extent, containing many Greek cities including the entire Syrian tetrapolis. Cleopatra, the wife of Tigranes the Great, invited Greeks such as the rhetor Amphicrates and the historian Metrodorus of Scepsis to the Armenian court, and - according to Plutarch - when the Roman general Lucullus seized the Armenian capital Tigranocerta, he found a troupe of Greek actors who had arrived to perform plays for Tigranes. Tigranes' successor Artavasdes II even composed Greek tragedies himself.

3. Philhellenic Kings: Some Armenian kings, including Tigranes the Great, are described as "Philhellenes," suggesting a favorable attitude towards Greece and Greek culture.

Tigranes' successor Artavasdes II even composed Greek tragedies himself.

articles.title: Strasbourg
articles.context: In 1871, after the end of the war, the city was annexed to the newly established German Empire as part of the Reichsland Elsass-Lothringen under the terms of the Treaty of Frankfurt. As part of Imperial Germany, Strasbourg was rebuilt and developed on a grand and representative scale, such as the Neue Stadt, or "new city" around the present Place de la République. Historian Rodolphe Reuss and Art historian Wilhelm von Bode were in charge of rebuilding the municipal archives, libraries and museums. The University, founded in 1567 and suppressed during the French Revolution as a stronghold of German sentiment,[citation needed] was reopened in 1872 under the name Kaiser-Wilhelms-Universität.

articles.title: History of science
articles.context: The English word scientist is relatively recent—first coined by William Whewell in the 19th century. Previously, people investigating nature called themselves natural philosophers. While empirical investigations of the natural world have been described since classical antiquity (for example, by Thales, Aristotle, and others), and scientific methods have been employed since the Middle Ages (for example, by Ibn al-Haytham, and Roger Bacon), the dawn of modern science is often traced back to the early modern period and in particular to the scientific revolution that took place in 16th- and 17th-century Europe. Scientific methods are considered to be so fundamental to modern science that some consider earlier inquiries into nature to be pre-scientific. Traditionally, historians of science have defined science sufficiently broadly to include those inquiries.

The Estonian National Defence Policy aim is to guarantee the preservation of the independence and sovereignty of the state, the integrity of its land, territorial waters, airspace and its constitutional order. Current strategic goals are to defend the country's interests, develop the armed forces for interoperability with other NATO and EU member forces, and participation in NATO missions.
